We’ve just taken our latest monetary policy decisions, determining what’s needed to achieve stable prices in the euro area. 

Tune into #TheECBPodcast to hear President Christine @Lagarde present the decisions in our press conference https://t.co/zGBR9pnfC0 https://t.co/8PCrNDETzt

We made changes to a number of our policy instruments.

We will discontinue net purchases under our pandemic emergency purchase programme at the end of March 2022.

Read more https://t.co/oLIbX9Wsuy

4/4 https://t.co/HP8H8XSCwE

For most of next year, inflation will remain above 2%.

But the factors pushing up prices will become weaker

3/4 https://t.co/LwBdhOmLng

Bottlenecks and delays will be with us for some time. But they should ease during 2022.

A solid labour market with many people in jobs should also help growth to pick up strongly again next year

2/4 https://t.co/AApZSqHHdl

Today’s monetary policy statement at a glance – a thread:

The pandemic has led to renewed restrictions in some countries.

Higher energy prices are slowing down the economy and will continue to do so in the near future

Leggi l’intervento di Fabio Panetta, Membro del Comitato esecutivo, sull’euro digitale e i suoi benefici https://t.co/zzU98BH2KL

Perché abbiamo bisogno di una moneta digitale della banca centrale? Il modo in cui effettuiamo i nostri acquisti sta cambiando e i cittadini devono poter usare uno strumento di pagamento sicuro e affidabile, offerto senza costi dallo Stato e accettato da tutti. https://t.co/ogNCZq1ITZ

Elderson: The #BaselCommittee has published principles for effectively managing and supervising climate-related financial risks. These principles will improve practices and provide a common baseline for banks and supervisors
3/3

Elderson: Analyses by the #BaselCommittee task force on climate-related financial risks have shown that we can tackle these risks using the traditional Basel framework risk categories. This will considerably speed up the actions of regulators and supervisors in this field
2/3

🧵 Banks are still a long way from treating climate-related and environmental exposures like other exposures, says Supervisory Board Vice-Chair @FrankElderson. But progress is being made in how these risks are supervised and managed https://t.co/2oLYmCagTb
1/3 https://t.co/ynnFw63tPI

Panetta: We have to work closely with consumers, intermediaries, firms and merchants to understand their needs. We must avoid being “too successful” by crowding out intermediaries and financial instruments, or “not successful enough” by generating insufficient demand
4/4

Panetta: Why do we need a digital euro? It would provide an anchor for digital payments at a time when the way we make our purchases is changing. Citizens must be able to use a simple, safe and reliable means of payment provided by the State and accepted everywhere
3/4

Panetta: As a digital euro would be issued by the central bank, its value would be guaranteed by the State. On the contrary, crypto-assets such as Bitcoin are notional instruments with no intrinsic value. Their value cannot be ensured 
2/4

🧵A digital euro would be a form of sovereign money provided in electronic format. It would be used by households, businesses and intermediaries to make or receive retail payments throughout the euro area, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta https://t.co/mCfEZKIadp
1/4 https://t.co/y2LGowDOlG
Euro area securities issues statistics (Oct 2021) https://t.co/kSVRCKqBZU

Credit risk remains high on our agenda, say Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria and Director of Supervisory Strategy and Risk Mario Quagliariello. Work must still be done on risks emerging from rapid digitalisation and the climate and environmental crisis https://t.co/u4aU2kegJz https://t.co/zINAcxfo85

We have set our supervisory priorities for 2022-2024. They aim to ensure banks:

➡️ emerge healthy from the pandemic
➡️ enhance their digitalisation and governance strategies
➡️ address emerging risks, including climate-related, IT and cyber risks

https://t.co/CYCFe7VJ3F https://t.co/MWhUFgKInR

We will ask people across Europe to provide input on the shortlisted banknote themes before we launch a design competition. We expect to pick the final design by 2024, when we will decide on launch dates 
3/3

The redesign process will start by gathering opinions from people across the euro area on ideas for new euro banknotes. A theme advisory group will then draw up a shortlist of themes
2/3

🧵We’re planning to redesign euro banknotes! Almost twenty years have passed since euro banknotes entered into circulation. We will soon launch the redesign process and expect to select new banknote designs by 2024. Press release https://t.co/a0FD2foa01
1/3 https://t.co/yMsCkumPWD

2/3

The outlook is less positive for sectors most affected by the pandemic. This is because the strong rise in insolvencies in those sectors has not been offset by an increase in new business registrations. Read more https://t.co/MbCDwyJo5D
2/2 https://t.co/z1bUDekfQ0

🧵 Fewer firms have defaulted during the pandemic than predicted by even the most optimistic forecasts, our Financial Stability Review shows. Economic growth in 2021 has helped firms to recover profits and repay their loans
1/2 https://t.co/LGroUIwKQ8
Working Paper: What are banks’ actual capital targets? https://t.co/L2Lj9jdIZI
Occasional Paper: Central Bank Digital Currency - Functional scope, pricing and controls https://t.co/qlCRBPMF2B

McCaul: Non-performing loans have fallen significantly, and our coverage expectations will help reduce them even more. If banks build on what they have achieved so far, they will be more robust and better able to support the recovery
3/3

🧵We are implementing a new bank-specific approach to ensure banks sufficiently provision for non-performing loans granted before April 2019, writes Supervisory Board member Elizabeth McCaul in #TheSupervisionBlog https://t.co/XLVUfzXB2I
1/3 https://t.co/3RUKpybAKg

De Guindos: For the time being, inflation expectations are a little below our inflation objective of 2%, but we need to remain vigilant to avoid second-round effects via wages. They could cause the upward inflationary trend to be more long-lasting
3/3

De Guindos: Base effects linked to supply problems and energy costs were stronger this year than envisaged. In 2022, bottlenecks may last longer than expected
2/3

🧵The factors behind the high rate of inflation we’re experiencing will not last, Vice-President Luis de Guindos told @LesEchos in an interview on 24 November. But there’s a risk that inflation will not go down as quickly and as much as we predicted https://t.co/JzCPFdu1Ej
1/3 https://t.co/9l3dxyuc9z

The challenges we face today are unprecedented, says President @Lagarde at the Accademia Nazionale dei Lincei. They can only be addressed by integrating scientific analysis into policymaking and recognising that we all have to act together. Read the speech https://t.co/9Qk6x3S444 https://t.co/n7rxcJC6Ta

We are about to reap the first benefits of applying supervisory technology, says Supervisory Board member Pentti Hakkarainen. As supervisors we need to embrace new tools and I am confident that the swift progress we have seen will continue https://t.co/TJfaUEAWww https://t.co/eXrQpM0aYS

Schnabel: Es wäre ein Fehler, die Zinsen frühzeitig anzuheben und damit den Aufschwung zu bremsen. Denn das würde zu einer höheren Arbeitslosigkeit führen und an der aktuellen Inflation nichts mehr ändern. 
Das ganze Interview https://t.co/4KB302sCFB  
3/3

Schnabel:  Wir sind dem Ziel der Preisstabilität verpflichtet. Wenn wir sehen, dass sich die Inflation mittelfristig auf einem höheren Niveau als 2 % festsetzen könnte, dann werden wir entschlossen reagieren. Aber im Moment gibt es darauf noch keine Hinweise 2/3

🧵Ich kann gut verstehen, dass viele Menschen sich Sorgen machen über die sehr hohen Inflationsraten, sagt @Isabel_Schnabel im @morgenmagazin. Wir gehen davon aus, dass die Inflation im nächsten Jahr allmählich wieder in Richtung unseres Ziels von 2 % zurückgehen wird 1/3 https://t.co/dXV81Kg0AT

Schnabel: It would be a mistake to raise interest rates prematurely and to thereby slow down the recovery. This would lead to higher unemployment but would not change the current inflation rate.
Watch the whole interview (in German) https://t.co/4KB302sCFB 
3/3

Schnabel: Our mandate is price stability. If we see that inflation exceeds our 2% inflation target in the medium term, we will respond decisively. But, at the moment, we don’t see this happening.
2/3

🧵I understand why many people are concerned about the current very high inflation rates, says @Isabel_Schnabel to @morgenmagazin. We expect inflation to gradually decline towards our 2% inflation target over the coming year.
1/3 https://t.co/yu6wLXwtEL
Watch live today from 08:35 CET: Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel is looking forward to talking about the current inflation in Germany at @ZDF @morgenmagazin https://t.co/ls09MHAJiC
Heute live ab 08:35 MEZ: Direktoriumsmitglied @Isabel_Schnabel spricht im @ZDF @morgenmagazin über die aktuelle Inflationsentwicklung https://t.co/ls09MHAJiC https://t.co/wlZT8E1SDq

Lagarde: Wenn wir erkennen, dass die Inflation auf mittlere Sicht, dauerhaft und nachhaltig unser Ziel von 2% erreicht, also nicht nur für kurze Zeit, können auch die Zinsen wieder steigen.

Niemand wird glücklicher sein als ich, dann die Geldpolitik zu normalisieren

3/3

Lagarde: Wenn wir jetzt die Geldpolitik straffen, hätten wir erst in 18 Monaten einen Effekt. Nach unseren Prognosen sinkt die Inflation bis dahin wieder.

Wir würden Arbeitslosigkeit verursachen, hätten aber die aktuell hohe Inflation nicht bekämpft. Das hielte ich für falsch.

🧵 Wir beobachten die Inflation sehr genau, sagt Präsidentin @Lagarde in einem Gespräch mit Gerald Braunberger von @FAZ_NET.

Nicht nur wegen unseres Preisstabilitätsziels, sondern auch, weil die Inflation die Menschen trifft, besonders die Ärmeren https://t.co/j9uTBFymBQ

1/3 https://t.co/2GdyDbtj4w
